utterance: OL: Just just to add to that, I actually had a conversation with someone at Total some months ago and you know, telling them all their chemistry and they were very excited and they said, what temperature does it run at? They would actually prefer that the the processes run about 60 degrees. And so when we talk about mechanisms and kinetics and thermodynamics, we need to really think about temperature seriously. And then we started thinking like, okay, well, well, can we induce heat resistively and have a cell that's intentionally resistive that allows us to reach a certain temperature level, right? And so that's kind of how we got down the rabbit hole of of trying to diagnose kind of how how thermal effects work. Um and um you know.

Then you will see unless you are able to do both things at the same time, spectroscopy and product detection, it's very difficult to relate the activity and selectivity of one catalyst that we see in a reactor to what you see in during the spectroscopy analysis. So it's challenging but I see obviously people working on these efforts and yeah, it's a challenge.
